title: Semantics Visualization for Fostering Search Result Comprehension
segmentation: But I will present here today in my talk is an approach for fostering search result comprehension in my research group that is called a semantics visualization at the Fraunhofer IGD in Germany.

We're doing some research and try to find out in which ways semantics information can be used in information visualizations to improve those visualizations and to better impart knowledge to the users.
I will start my talk today with a short introduction, then present.

And our approach for visualizing search results and semantic domains and give a short introduction of the application scenario where we use our approach and finally present the results of an evaluation and give a prospect of future work.
Yeah, the optimal use of data.
Place a major role not only in global competition, but also for the competitiveness of industrial companies.
In this field, semantic technologies provide adequate tools for improving data handling, and, in particular, for linking heater Agenus data sources for generating product contexts.
And of course, also for facilitating information access.
Today, these technologies are already included in daily search process, is for improving search results.
Usually the search results are presented in sorted text and mainly in textual form.

The semantic information that remains remains in most cases hidden from the user in such presentations, although this information can support users in information seeking tasks and particular in search results.
So we developed a novel approach for utilizing the semantic information in information visualization that represents search results.
The objective of our approach was to support users in.
Relevance assessment tasks of these results, and we also show in this visualization query result relations.
As you will see later in the talk and also integrated or feature that we call Wizard feedback for query enhancement that supports the common search strategy of users.
The approach I present here today is based on the same as framework that we.
Developed in our group that is realization framework for semantics knowledge.
If you are interested in this, I can give you a short demonstration after the talk.
The framework contains different aspect oriented visualization techniques.
For example, there are geographical realizations of time realizations.
All of them make use of semantics, information for improving the Rizal presentation, and today this framework is used in several application scenarios and use cases.
The approach I will present here today is based on and force base layout algorithm.
This algorithm places nodes on a 2 dimensional space on a surface on a 2 dimensional by assigning different forces to edges and nodes of the crafts and then.

Adapting these different forces in an iterative simulation until the mechanical equilibrium is reached, I skipped all the mathematical details at this point here, in contrast to other force base layout algorithms, we adapted the different forces by using different similarities that emerged during the semantic retrieval process you will see.
That later on a later slide here on this slide you can see.
Screenshot of our approach you can see here in the center.
This all call it recited notes that represent the search results.
They are suspended between different attribute nodes around them.
These in the center that notes that are positioned by the force layout algorithm according to the similarities that emerged during the semantic result retrieval.
The attributes are then placed in a circular form during the initialization process of that realization and users.
Able to freely move these attribute nodes.
Each query term is then presented in such an ad.
Compute node and Additionally the semantic meaning is shown in the node label.

Though users are able to assess enrich Ray there semantic search processing in the background interprets such an given query term, and finally the relations between those query terms in the attribute nodes visualized with directed edges between those attribute nodes and the result nodes.
Here on the left side you can see an example of this visualization approach.
The approach reveals that only one of these five search results is semantically related to the query application area, namely, a construction industry on the right side you see another example.
There are also query term cylinder and you can see here that the semantic search engine in the background disambiguates this surgery in two different rates, on the one hand.

It interprets the term cylinder as a shape of an object and on the other hand as a function carrier, and the user is able with this kind of visualization to unambiguously determine the most relevant results for his individual search.
Another important issue for assessing search results and semantic domains relates to semantic neighborhood of resources that can be in some way responsible for the recycle retrieval.

That means that search result can be found by considering source semantic structures, and it might be very difficult for the user to assess the search result for that reason and to enable the user to comprehend why certain search results are considered as relevant and adequate feedback mechanism is needed for.
For for making the user able to decide which of the results are important for this individual search.
The solution we integrated in the visualization was expandable attribute node that contains resources from the semantic neighborhoods that are of some kind.
Of some relevance for the result generation, the labels of these expandable attribute nodes are derived from the control and concept of the semantic structure of the neighborhood objects.
You can see such an example.
This is a realization of the query site relations combined with the semantic neighborhood.
You can see here.

In this case it is a bottle and this bottle.
Relates to the given query terms so users are able to.
Assess the search result in our able to understand why these results are retrieved by the semantic search processing in the background.
Besides the visualization of relations between query terms and retrieve results.
The proposed approach utilizes different semantic similarities that are emerged during search results retrieval.
As I mentioned before.
And we use these similarities to map them to visual attributes for improving the realization approach.
On the one hand, we use partial similarities.
These are measured between the attribute nodes and the result values.
The result resources.
They can be seen as a representation of the relevance of the retrieved resources to a given query term, and we use these partial similarities to adapt the writes.

The weights between the edges and so between the attribute nodes and the result nodes, and this results in different length of the visible connections and indicates the relevance between specific query terms.
And the search results so user is able to understand which of the given query terms which result relates the most.
Additionally, we use result similarities.

These can be seen as aggregated partial similarities that correspond to the overall relevance of the retrieved results, and we use them and map these result similarities to the size and the color of the result nodes.
Yeah, another issue was the common search strategy that we used to support with our approach.
The common search strategy is.
Brand new.

User searching and information retrieval systems is to reformulate or to enhance the queries he entered in the search engine and if we use this common search strategy and transfer it to our visualization approach, this corresponds to substitutions or reassignments of those attribute nodes that you have seen before.
That means that an instantiation of an additional attribute defines a more specific search condition, whereas a removal.
Often attribute value results in a rider ranged and less specific search space.
So what we have done, we used different attributes that are not instantiated by the query.
That means that there are attributes in the result set and no query term could be related to those attributes and recommended those uninstantiated attribute nodes in the visualization.
The nice thing about that is when the user selects and suggested query term for such an uninstantiated attribute that ranges are immediately visible in the visualization.
As you can see here.
Here are three diff.
Current nodes attributes that are not that could not be related to the given query term, and the realization recommends different.
Yeah, terms for such an attribute, for example, in this case it recommends different function carriers and if the user selects option function carrier in this case it's in Cowra 150.
That is, some kind of robot I think.
Then the visualization immediately reveals which of the search results are related to the selected.
To this selected attribute.
Yeah, let me say a few words about the application scenario where we use.

This visualization we applied it in the field of mechanical engineering that is a high complex that is carrier characterized by high, highly complex process is they start from initial developments of construction to production steps and also consumer services.
And this.

Field, you have diverse user groups and that means that one resource is treated in very different contexts and our partners in this project have used different semantic technologies to link different knowledge bases.
They have developed an Audubon, toiletry, and provided the semantic search engine in the background and with the overall objective to provide novel way to access this information.
And yeah, the goal of our resort isation approach was to provide an homogeneous access to this knowledge base.
And of course to provide more transparency and search processing.
If you are interested.
Here is also a link to this approach I presented here today.
It's also included in the paper and you can try it yourself and play a little bit around with this visualization approach.
So for evaluating our approach, we also performed user study.
Compared our visualization with a common list presentation, that of course contains all the same information content.
The goal of our evaluation was to answer questions like is a user really supported in assessing search result and satisfies our approach.
The needs of the user.
So we formulated.
Yeah, so we formulated a hypothesis.

Namely, there's a difference in task completion time between the list representation and the visualization in assessing search results and also take different subjective evaluation criteria into account.
Like for example the user satisfaction.
The experimental design of our user study was basic within group design and such.
In design, each participant accomplished the given tasks.

In each condition, that means in our case, in the list presentation and in the visualization and for preventing possible learn effects when switching between those post conditions, we control those learning effects by systematic randomization of.
On the one hand the conditions and of course the tasks and ordered them randomized in a randomized form between each participant.
Also, we advise participants to disregard the knowledge from previous condition and also authorized them in explicitly showing the solutions on the Queen on the screen.
All together we define three different tasks.
For our evaluation we pre assigned the queries to ensure that each participant retrieves the same visual representation.
And in the first task, the user users had to identify relations between each search result and the given query terms, and the second task that was very similar to the first task.
With a difference that we got such hierarchical structures as I presented before in the result set and in the third task, the.
The users had to identify most relevant search results for specific search scenario.
Set a time limit for each task that was set to three minutes and wrong answers were also estimated with three minutes.
Altogether, 17 participants attended the evaluation.
They were mainly graduates and students average age roles.
2429 and participants were mainly involved in computer science.
The general procedure for each participant was we gave 1st and general introduction into the whole evaluation process, then give a brief introduction to both systems.
On the one side, the visualization approach and the list presentation.
We created them with an exemplary query and users were also allowed to.
Ask questions concerning the different systems.

After that, the participants had to accomplish the three different tasks and after each task and condition they had to rank their satisfaction and Additionally they had to answer 5 different questions concerning their subjective opinion.
Finally, after the task accomplishment they had to answer a brief demographic question now.
You can see the results.
The resort Lusatian performed very well in our scenario.
Concerning the.
The the task completion time, the list presentation achieved an average of 88 eight seconds, whereas visualization achieved an average of 51.3 seconds.
Paired sample T test also revealed that there was a significant difference in task completion time, so we were able to refute the null hypothesis and the alternative hypothesis can be confirmed.
Also, the user satisfaction ratings after each task that were measured on a scale from 1 to 9.
Reveal that the users prefer our visualization approach to the list presentation.
Realization achieved an average ranking of 757, whereas the list presentation achieved a ranking of 5.3 run.
Additionally, the results of the question, would you use the system in the future for similar search tasks?
Confirms the assumption that users prefer the visualization approach to the list presentation.
Here you can also see the task completion times and user satisfaction rankings.

Also.
The results showed that the proposed approach works very well in our domain.
There still had to be further investigations there.
